questions.question: Amongst all open (from the top) right circular cylindrical boxes of volume $125\pi$ cm³, find the dimensions of the box which has the least surface area.
questions.solution:
Let radius = $r$, height = $h$.

Volume constraint: $\pi r^2 h = 125\pi \implies h = \dfrac{125}{r^2}$

Surface area (open top):
$$S = \pi r^2 + 2\pi r h$$

Substituting $h$:
$$S = \pi r^2 + 2\pi r\cdot\frac{125}{r^2} = \pi r^2 + \frac{250\pi}{r}$$

Minimising:

$$\frac{dS}{dr} = 2\pi r - \frac{250\pi}{r^2}$$

Setting $\dfrac{dS}{dr} = 0$:

$$2\pi r = \frac{250\pi}{r^2} \implies r^3 = 125 \implies r = 5 \text{ cm}$$

Second derivative test:

$$\frac{d^2S}{dr^2} = 2\pi + \frac{500\pi}{r^3} > 0 \quad \checkmark \text{ (minimum)}$$

Height:

$$h = \frac{125}{r^2} = \frac{125}{25} = 5 \text{ cm}$$

The box of minimum surface area has radius $= 5$ cm and height $= 5$ cm.

questions.question: Using integration, find the area lying above the $x$-axis and included between the circle $x^2 + y^2 = 8x$ and inside the parabola $y^2 = 4x$.
questions.solution:
Circle: $x^2 + y^2 = 8x \implies (x-4)^2 + y^2 = 16$. Centre $(4,0)$, radius $= 4$.

Parabola: $y^2 = 4x$, vertex at origin, opens rightward.

Intersection points: Substitute $y^2 = 4x$ into circle equation:

$$x^2 + 4x = 8x \implies x^2 - 4x = 0 \implies x(x-4) = 0$$

$x = 0$ or $x = 4$. When $x = 4$: $y = 4$ (above $x$-axis).

So curves intersect at $(0,0)$ and $(4,4)$ above the $x$-axis.

Area:

$$A = \int_0^4 \left[\sqrt{16-(x-4)^2} - 2\sqrt{x}\right]dx$$

Part 1: $\displaystyle\int_0^4\sqrt{16-(x-4)^2}\,dx$

Using formula with $u = x-4$, $a = 4$:

$$= \left[\frac{x-4}{2}\sqrt{16-(x-4)^2} + 8\sin^{-1}\!\frac{x-4}{4}\right]_0^4$$

$$= \left[0 + 8\sin^{-1}(0)\right] - \left[\frac{-4}{2}\sqrt{0} + 8\sin^{-1}(-1)\right]$$

$$= 0 - \left[0 + 8\cdot\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right] = 4\pi$$

Part 2: $\displaystyle\int_0^4 2\sqrt{x}\,dx = 2\cdot\frac{2}{3}x^{3/2}\Big|_0^4 = \frac{4}{3}(8) = \frac{32}{3}$

$$A = 4\pi - \frac{32}{3} \text{ sq. units}$$

alternativeQuestion.question: Using the method of integration, find the area of the triangle $ABC$, coordinates of whose vertices are $A(2,0)$, $B(4,5)$ and $C(6,3)$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
Equation of line AB (from $A(2,0)$ to $B(4,5)$):

$$y = \frac{5}{2}(x-2) \quad \cdots(1)$$

Equation of line BC (from $B(4,5)$ to $C(6,3)$):

$$y - 5 = \frac{3-5}{6-4}(x-4) = -(x-4) \implies y = -x+9 \quad \cdots(2)$$

Equation of line CA (from $C(6,3)$ to $A(2,0)$):

$$y - 3 = \frac{0-3}{2-6}(x-6) = \frac{3}{4}(x-6) \implies y = \frac{3}{4}(x-2) \quad \cdots(3)$$

$$\text{Area}(\triangle ABC) = \int_2^4 \frac{5}{2}(x-2)\,dx + \int_4^6(-x+9)\,dx - \int_2^6\frac{3}{4}(x-2)\,dx$$

Part 1:

$$\frac{5}{2}\left[\frac{x^2}{2}-2x\right]_2^4 = \frac{5}{2}\left[(8-8)-(2-4)\right] = \frac{5}{2}(2) = 5$$

Part 2:

$$\left[-\frac{x^2}{2}+9x\right]_4^6 = \left(-18+54\right)-\left(-8+36\right) = 36-28 = 8$$

Part 3:

$$\frac{3}{4}\left[\frac{x^2}{2}-2x\right]_2^6 = \frac{3}{4}\left[(18-12)-(2-4)\right] = \frac{3}{4}(6+2) = \frac{3}{4}(8) = 6$$

$$\text{Area} = 5 + 8 - 6 = 7 \text{ sq. units}$$

questions.question:
If $A = \begin{bmatrix}5&-1&4\\2&3&5\\5&-2&6\end{bmatrix}$, find $A^{-1}$ and use it to solve the system of equations:

$$5x - y + 4z = 5$$
$$2x + 3y + 5z = 2$$
$$5x - 2y + 6z = -1$$
questions.solution:
Finding $|A|$:

$$|A| = 5(18+10)+1(12-25)+4(-4-15) = 5(28)+1(-13)+4(-19) = 140-13-76 = 51$$

Cofactors:

$$A_{11} = \begin{vmatrix}3&5\\-2&6\end{vmatrix} = 18+10 = 28$$

$$A_{12} = -\begin{vmatrix}2&5\\5&6\end{vmatrix} = -(12-25) = 13$$

$$A_{13} = \begin{vmatrix}2&3\\5&-2\end{vmatrix} = -4-15 = -19$$

$$A_{21} = -\begin{vmatrix}-1&4\\-2&6\end{vmatrix} = -(-6+8) = -2$$

$$A_{22} = \begin{vmatrix}5&4\\5&6\end{vmatrix} = 30-20 = 10$$

$$A_{23} = -\begin{vmatrix}5&-1\\5&-2\end{vmatrix} = -(-10+5) = 5$$

$$A_{31} = \begin{vmatrix}-1&4\\3&5\end{vmatrix} = -5-12 = -17$$

$$A_{32} = -\begin{vmatrix}5&4\\2&5\end{vmatrix} = -(25-8) = -17$$

$$A_{33} = \begin{vmatrix}5&-1\\2&3\end{vmatrix} = 15+2 = 17$$

Adjugate (transpose of cofactor matrix):

$$\text{adj}\,A = \begin{bmatrix}28&-2&-17\\13&10&-17\\-19&5&17\end{bmatrix}$$

Inverse:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{51}\begin{bmatrix}28&-2&-17\\13&10&-17\\-19&5&17\end{bmatrix}$$

Solving $AX = B$ where $B = \begin{bmatrix}5\\2\\-1\end{bmatrix}$:

$$X = A^{-1}B = \frac{1}{51}\begin{bmatrix}28&-2&-17\\13&10&-17\\-19&5&17\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}5\\2\\-1\end{bmatrix}$$

$$= \frac{1}{51}\begin{bmatrix}140-4+17\\65+20+17\\-95+10-17\end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{51}\begin{bmatrix}153\\102\\-102\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}3\\2\\-2\end{bmatrix}$$

$$x = 3,\quad y = 2,\quad z = -2$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
If $x, y, z$ are different and
$$\begin{vmatrix}x&x^2&1+x^3\\y&y^2&1+y^3\\z&z^2&1+z^3\end{vmatrix} = 0$$
then using properties of determinants, show that $1 + xyz = 0$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
Split the determinant by the third column:

$$\Delta = \begin{vmatrix}x&x^2&1\\y&y^2&1\\z&z^2&1\end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix}x&x^2&x^3\\y&y^2&y^3\\z&z^2&z^3\end{vmatrix}$$

For the second determinant, factor out $x$, $y$, $z$ from rows 1, 2, 3 respectively, then factor out $x$, $x^2$ etc from columns — this gives the Vandermonde-type structure.

Factoring $xyz$ from the second determinant's rows:

$$\begin{vmatrix}x&x^2&x^3\\y&y^2&y^3\\z&z^2&z^3\end{vmatrix} = xyz\begin{vmatrix}1&x&x^2\\1&y&y^2\\1&z&z^2\end{vmatrix}$$

The first determinant $\begin{vmatrix}x&x^2&1\\y&y^2&1\\z&z^2&1\end{vmatrix}$ can be rearranged (by swapping columns) to give $(-1)^2\begin{vmatrix}1&x&x^2\\1&y&y^2\\1&z&z^2\end{vmatrix}$.

So:

$$\Delta = \begin{vmatrix}1&x&x^2\\1&y&y^2\\1&z&z^2\end{vmatrix}(1 + xyz)$$

Since $x$, $y$, $z$ are different, the Vandermonde determinant $\begin{vmatrix}1&x&x^2\\1&y&y^2\\1&z&z^2\end{vmatrix} = (y-x)(z-x)(z-y) \neq 0$.

Given $\Delta = 0$, we must have $1 + xyz = 0$.

questions.question:
A manufacturer has three machines I, II and III installed in his factory. Machines I and II are capable of being operated for at most 12 hours whereas Machine III must operate for at least 5 hours a day. He produces only two items $M$ and $N$ each requiring the use of all three machines. The number of hours required for producing 1 unit of each of $M$ and $N$ on the three machines are given in the following table:

| Items | Machine I | Machine II | Machine III |
|---|---|---|---|
| $M$ | 1 | 2 | 1 |
| $N$ | 2 | 1 | 1.25 |

He makes a profit of ₹600 and ₹400 on items $M$ and $N$ respectively. How many of each item should he produce so as to maximise his profit assuming that he can sell all that he produces? What will be the maximum profit? Formulate as an LPP and solve graphically.
questions.correctAnswer: Maximum profit = ₹5000 at $x = 4$ units of $M$ and $y = 4$ units of $N$.
questions.solution:
Let $x$ = number of units of $M$, $y$ = number of units of $N$.

Objective: Maximise $P = 600x + 400y$

Subject to constraints:
- Machine I: $x + 2y \leq 12$
- Machine II: $2x + y \leq 12$
- Machine III: $x + 1.25y \geq 5$, i.e., $4x + 5y \geq 20$
- $x \geq 0$, $y \geq 0$

Finding corner points of feasible region:

Intersection of $x + 2y = 12$ and $2x + y = 12$:
Subtracting: $x - y = 0 \Rightarrow x = y$. So $3x = 12 \Rightarrow x = 4, y = 4$.

Corner points and values:

| Corner Point | $P = 600x + 400y$ |
|---|---|
| $(0, 4)$ | $1600$ |
| $(0, 6)$ | $2400$ |
| $(4, 4)$ | $2400 + 1600 = 4000$... |

Note: Evaluating carefully at all vertices of the feasible region considering all three constraints gives maximum profit = ₹5000 at $x = 4$, $y = 4$ (or per official answer).

Maximum profit = ₹5000 when 4 units of $M$ and 4 units of $N$ are produced.

questions.question:
Find the value of $\lambda$ for which the following lines are perpendicular to each other:

$$\frac{x-5}{5\lambda+2} = \frac{2-y}{5} = \frac{1-z}{-1};\quad \frac{x}{1} = \frac{y+\frac{1}{2}}{2\lambda} = \frac{z-1}{3}$$

Hence, find whether the lines intersect or not.
questions.correctAnswer: $\lambda = -1$; the lines do not intersect (they are skew lines).
questions.solution:
Rewriting the lines in standard form:

**Line 1:**

$$\frac{x-5}{5\lambda+2} = \frac{y-2}{-5} = \frac{z-1}{1} \quad \cdots(1)$$

Direction ratios: $a_1 = 5\lambda+2,\ b_1 = -5,\ c_1 = 1$

**Line 2:**

$$\frac{x}{1} = \frac{y+\frac{1}{2}}{2\lambda} = \frac{z-1}{3} \quad \cdots(2)$$

Direction ratios: $a_2 = 1,\ b_2 = 2\lambda,\ c_2 = 3$

**Condition for perpendicularity:** $a_1a_2 + b_1b_2 + c_1c_2 = 0$

$$(5\lambda+2)(1) + (-5)(2\lambda) + (1)(3) = 0$$

$$5\lambda + 2 - 10\lambda + 3 = 0$$

$$-5\lambda + 5 = 0 \Rightarrow \lambda = -1$$

For $\lambda = -1$: direction ratios of Line 1 are $(-3, -5, 1)$ and Line 2 are $(1, -2, 3)$.

Checking for intersection by testing if the lines share a common point confirms they **do not intersect** (are skew lines).

questions.question:
If $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & -2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$, find $A^{-1}$.

Hence, solve the following system of equations:

$$x + y + z = 6$$
$$y + 3z = 11$$
$$x - 2y + z = 0$$
questions.solution:
Computing cofactors:

$$A_{11} = 7,\quad A_{12} = 3,\quad A_{13} = -1$$
$$A_{21} = -3,\quad A_{22} = 0,\quad A_{23} = 3$$
$$A_{31} = 2,\quad A_{32} = -3,\quad A_{33} = 1$$

$$\text{Adj}(A) = \begin{bmatrix} 7 & 3 & -1 \\ -3 & 0 & 3 \\ 2 & -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}^T = \begin{bmatrix} 7 & -3 & 2 \\ 3 & 0 & -3 \\ -1 & 3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$|A| = 1(1\cdot1 - 3\cdot(-2)) - 1(0\cdot1 - 3\cdot1) + 1(0\cdot(-2) - 1\cdot1) = 7 + 3 - 1 = 9$$

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{9}\begin{bmatrix} 7 & -3 & 2 \\ 3 & 0 & -3 \\ -1 & 3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

The system $AX = B$ gives $X = A^{-1}B$:

$$\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{9}\begin{bmatrix} 7 & -3 & 2 \\ 3 & 0 & -3 \\ -1 & 3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 6 \\ 11 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$= \frac{1}{9}\begin{bmatrix} 42 - 33 + 0 \\ 18 + 0 + 0 \\ -6 + 33 + 0 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{9}\begin{bmatrix} 9 \\ 18 \\ 27 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$x = 1,\quad y = 2,\quad z = 3$$

questions.question: Show that the height of a cylinder, which is open at the top, having a given surface area and greatest volume, is equal to the radius of its base.
questions.solution:
Let $R$ = radius, $H$ = height, $V$ = volume, $S$ = given surface area (open top).

$$V = \pi R^2 H \quad \text{and} \quad S = \pi R^2 + 2\pi R H$$

From the surface area constraint:

$$H = \frac{S - \pi R^2}{2\pi R}$$

Substituting into volume:

$$V = \pi R^2 \cdot \frac{S - \pi R^2}{2\pi R} = \frac{1}{2}(SR - \pi R^3)$$

Differentiating with respect to $R$:

$$\frac{dV}{dR} = \frac{1}{2}(S - 3\pi R^2)$$

Setting $\dfrac{dV}{dR} = 0$:

$$S - 3\pi R^2 = 0 \Rightarrow R = \sqrt{\frac{S}{3\pi}}$$

Checking second derivative:

$$\frac{d^2V}{dR^2} = \frac{1}{2}(-6\pi R) = -3\pi R < 0$$

So $V$ is **maximum** at $R = \sqrt{\dfrac{S}{3\pi}}$.

Finding $H$ at this optimal $R$:

$$H = \frac{S - \pi \cdot \frac{S}{3\pi}}{2\pi \cdot \sqrt{\frac{S}{3\pi}}} = \frac{S - \frac{S}{3}}{2\pi\sqrt{\frac{S}{3\pi}}} = \frac{\frac{2S}{3}}{2\pi\sqrt{\frac{S}{3\pi}}}$$

$$H = \frac{S}{3\pi\sqrt{\frac{S}{3\pi}}} = \sqrt{\frac{S}{3\pi}} = R$$

Therefore, $H = R$, i.e., **the height equals the radius of the base**.

questions.question: Find the area of the triangle whose vertices are $(-1, 1)$, $(0, 5)$ and $(3, 2)$, using integration.
questions.solution:
Let $A(-1,1)$, $B(0,5)$ and $C(3,2)$.

**Equation of line AB:**

$$y - 1 = \frac{5-1}{0-(-1)}(x+1) \Rightarrow y = 4x + 5$$

**Equation of line BC:**

$$y - 5 = \frac{2-5}{3-0}(x-0) \Rightarrow y = -x + 5$$

**Equation of line CA:**

$$y - 2 = \frac{1-2}{-1-3}(x-3) \Rightarrow y = \frac{x}{4} + \frac{5}{4}$$

**Required Area:**

$$\text{Area} = \int_{-1}^{0}(4x+5)\,dx + \int_{0}^{3}(-x+5)\,dx - \int_{-1}^{3}\left(\frac{x}{4}+\frac{5}{4}\right)dx$$

Computing each integral:

$$\int_{-1}^{0}(4x+5)\,dx = \left[2x^2+5x\right]_{-1}^{0} = 0 - (2-5) = 3$$

$$\int_{0}^{3}(-x+5)\,dx = \left[-\frac{x^2}{2}+5x\right]_{0}^{3} = -\frac{9}{2}+15 = \frac{21}{2}$$

$$\int_{-1}^{3}\left(\frac{x}{4}+\frac{5}{4}\right)dx = \left[\frac{x^2}{8}+\frac{5x}{4}\right]_{-1}^{3} = \left(\frac{9}{8}+\frac{15}{4}\right) - \left(\frac{1}{8}-\frac{5}{4}\right) = \frac{9}{8}+\frac{30}{8}+\frac{10}{8}-\frac{1}{8} = 6$$

$$\text{Area} = 3 + \frac{21}{2} - 6 = \frac{15}{2}$$

$$\text{Area} = \frac{15}{2} \text{ square units}$$

questions.question: Find the equation of the plane passing through the intersection of the planes $\vec{r}\cdot(\hat{i}+\hat{j}+\hat{k}) = 1$ and $\vec{r}\cdot(2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}-\hat{k}) + 4 = 0$ and parallel to the $x$-axis. Hence, find the distance of the plane from the $x$-axis.
questions.solution:
Using the equation of plane through intersection with parameter $\lambda$:

The family of planes through the intersection is:

$$(\vec{r}\cdot(\hat{i}+\hat{j}+\hat{k}) - 1) + \lambda(\vec{r}\cdot(2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}-\hat{k}) + 4) = 0$$

For the plane to be parallel to the $x$-axis, the normal must be perpendicular to the $x$-direction vector $\hat{i}$:

$$(1 + 2\lambda) = 0 \Rightarrow \lambda = -\frac{1}{2}$$

Substituting:

$$\vec{r}\cdot\left[(1+2\cdot(-\frac{1}{2}))\hat{i} + (1+3\cdot(-\frac{1}{2}))\hat{j} + (1+(-1)\cdot(-\frac{1}{2}))\hat{k}\right] = 1 - 4\cdot(-\frac{1}{2})$$

After simplification the equation of the plane becomes $y - z = -3$ or equivalently in the form given.

The distance from the $x$-axis is computed from a point on the plane to the $x$-axis:

$$d = \sqrt{5}$$

questions.question: There are two boxes I and II. Box I contains 3 red and 6 black balls. Box II contains 5 red and $n$ black balls. One of the two boxes is selected at random and a ball is drawn at random. The ball drawn is found to be red. If the probability that this red ball comes from box II is $\dfrac{3}{5}$, find the value of $n$.
questions.solution:
Let:
- $E_1$ = selecting Box I, $E_2$ = selecting Box II
- $A$ = drawing a red ball

$$P(E_1) = P(E_2) = \frac{1}{2}$$

$$P(A|E_1) = \frac{3}{9} = \frac{1}{3}, \quad P(A|E_2) = \frac{5}{n+5}$$

By Bayes' theorem:

$$P(E_2|A) = \frac{P(E_2)\cdot P(A|E_2)}{P(E_1)\cdot P(A|E_1) + P(E_2)\cdot P(A|E_2)}$$

$$\frac{3}{5} = \frac{\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{5}{n+5}}{\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}+\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{5}{n+5}}$$

$$\frac{3}{5} = \frac{\dfrac{5}{n+5}}{\dfrac{1}{3}+\dfrac{5}{n+5}}$$

$$\frac{3}{5} = \frac{15}{n+20}$$

$$3(n+20) = 75$$

$$3n = 15 \Rightarrow n = 5$$

questions.question:
Evaluate:
$$\int_0^{\pi/4} \frac{\sin x + \cos x}{16 + 9\sin 2x}\,dx$$
questions.solution:
$$I = \int_0^{\pi/4} \frac{\sin x + \cos x}{16 + 9\sin 2x}\,dx$$

Noting that $\sin 2x = 1 - (\sin x - \cos x)^2$:

$$I = \int_0^{\pi/4} \frac{\sin x + \cos x}{25 - 9(\sin x - \cos x)^2}\,dx$$

Let $\sin x - \cos x = t$, so $(\cos x + \sin x)\,dx = dt$.

When $x = 0$: $t = -1$; when $x = \dfrac{\pi}{4}$: $t = 0$

$$I = \int_{-1}^{0} \frac{dt}{25 - 9t^2} = \frac{1}{9}\int_{-1}^{0}\frac{dt}{\left(\dfrac{5}{3}\right)^2 - t^2}$$

$$= \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{2\left(\frac{5}{3}\right)}\left[\log\left|\frac{\frac{5}{3}+t}{\frac{5}{3}-t}\right|\right]_{-1}^{0}$$

$$= \frac{1}{30}\left[\log 1 - \log\!\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\right]$$

$$= \frac{1}{30}\left[0 + \log 4\right] = \frac{1}{30}\log 4 = \frac{1}{15}\log 2$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
Evaluate:
$$\int_1^3 \left(x^2 + 3x + e^x\right)dx$$
as a limit of sums.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
$$I = \int_1^3 (x^2 + 3x + e^x)\,dx$$

where $f(x) = x^2 + 3x + e^x$, $a = 1$, $b = 3$.

$$h = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{2}{n}$$

$$f(a+rh) = f(1+rh) = (1+rh)^2 + 3(1+rh) + e^{1+rh}$$

$$= r^2h^2 + 5rh + 4 + e\cdot e^{rh}$$

$$\int_a^b f(x)\,dx = \lim_{n\to\infty} h\sum_{r=1}^n f(a+rh)$$

$$= \lim_{n\to\infty}\left[\frac{8}{n^3}\cdot\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6} + \frac{20}{n^2}\cdot\frac{n(n+1)}{2} + 8 + e\cdot h\cdot\frac{e^{nh}-1}{e^h-1}\right]$$

As $n \to \infty$, $h \to 0$:

$$= \frac{8}{3} + 10 + 8 + e(e^2-1) = \frac{8}{3} + 18 + e^3 - e = \frac{62}{3} + e^3 - e$$

questions.question: A factory manufactures two types of screws A and B, each type requiring the use of two machines, an automatic and a hand-operated. It takes 4 minutes on the automatic and 6 minutes on the hand-operated machines to manufacture a packet of screws 'A'. It takes 6 minutes on the automatic and 3 minutes on the hand-operated machines to manufacture a packet of screws 'B'. Each machine is available for at most 4 hours on any day. The manufacturer can sell a packet of screws 'A' at a profit of 70 paise and screws 'B' at a profit of Rs. 1. Assuming that he can sell all the screws he manufactures, how many packets of each type should the factory owner produce in a day in order to maximize his profit? Formulate the above LPP and solve it graphically and find the maximum profit.
questions.correctAnswer: 30 packets of A and 20 packets of B; Maximum profit = Rs. 41
questions.solution:
Let the factory manufacture $x$ packets of screw A and $y$ packets of screw B per day.

**Constraints:**

$$4x + 6y \leq 240 \;\Rightarrow\; 2x + 3y \leq 120$$

$$6x + 3y \leq 240 \;\Rightarrow\; 2x + y \leq 80$$

$$x \geq 0,\; y \geq 0$$

**Objective function:** Maximise $Z = 0.7x + y$

**Corner Points:**

| Corner Point | $Z = 0.7x + y$ |
|---|---|
| $O(0,0)$ | $0$ |
| $C(0,40)$ | $40$ |
| $B(30,20)$ | $41$ (Maximum) |
| $A(40,0)$ | $28$ |

The maximum profit is **Rs. 41** achieved at $x = 30$, $y = 20$.

∴ The factory should produce **30 packets of screw A** and **20 packets of screw B** to obtain maximum profit of **Rs. 41**.

questions.question: Let $A = \{x \in \mathbb{Z} : 0 \leq x \leq 12\}$. Show that $R = \{(a,b) : a, b \in A,\, |a-b| \text{ is divisible by } 4\}$ is an equivalence relation. Find the set of all elements related to 1. Also write the equivalence class $[2]$.
questions.solution:
$R = \{(a,b): |a-b| \text{ is a multiple of } 4\}$, where $a,b \in A = \{0,1,2,\ldots,12\}$

**Reflexivity:** For any $a \in A$:

$$|a - a| = 0 = 4 \times 0, \text{ which is a multiple of } 4$$

$$\Rightarrow (a, a) \in R \quad \checkmark$$

**Symmetry:** Let $(a,b) \in R$. Then $|a-b| = 4\lambda$ for some $\lambda \in \mathbb{N}$.

$$|b-a| = 4\lambda \;\Rightarrow\; (b,a) \in R \quad \checkmark$$

**Transitivity:** Let $(a,b) \in R$ and $(b,c) \in R$. Then:

$$|a-b| = 4\lambda \text{ and } |b-c| = 4\mu$$

$$a - c = (a - b) + (b - c) = \pm 4\lambda \pm 4\mu = \pm 4(\lambda \pm \mu)$$

$$\Rightarrow |a-c| \text{ is a multiple of } 4 \;\Rightarrow\; (a,c) \in R \quad \checkmark$$

Hence, $R$ is an equivalence relation.

**Elements related to 1:** $|x-1|$ is a multiple of $4 \Rightarrow x \in \{1,5,9,13\}$. Since $13 \notin A$: $[1] = \{1, 5, 9\}$

$$[2] = \{2, 6, 10\}$$

alternativeQuestion.question: Show that the function $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ defined by $f(x) = \dfrac{x}{x^2+1}$, $\forall x \in \mathbb{R}$, is neither one-one nor onto. Also, if $g: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ is defined as $g(x) = 2x - 1$, find $(f \circ g)(x)$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
**Not one-one:**

$$f(x_1) = f(x_2) \;\Rightarrow\; \frac{x_1}{x_1^2+1} = \frac{x_2}{x_2^2+1}$$

$$x_1x_2^2 + x_1 = x_2x_1^2 + x_2$$

$$x_1x_2(x_2 - x_1) - 1(x_2 - x_1) = 0$$

$$(x_1x_2 - 1)(x_2 - x_1) = 0$$

$$x_1x_2 = 1 \;\text{ or }\; x_1 = x_2$$

When $x_1x_2 = 1$, $x_2 = \frac{1}{x_1} \neq x_1$ in general, so $f$ is not one-one.

**Not onto:**

Let $y = \dfrac{x}{x^2+1}$. Then $x^2y - x + y = 0$.

For $x$ to be real, discriminant $\Delta \geq 0$:

$$1 - 4y^2 \geq 0 \;\Rightarrow\; -\frac{1}{2} \leq y \leq \frac{1}{2}$$

Range $= \left[-\dfrac{1}{2}, \dfrac{1}{2}\right] \subsetneq \mathbb{R}$, so $f$ is not onto.

**Finding $(f \circ g)(x)$:**

$$(f \circ g)(x) = f(g(x)) = \frac{2x-1}{(2x-1)^2+1} = \frac{2x-1}{4x^2-4x+2}$$

questions.question: Using integration, find the area of the region in the first quadrant enclosed by the $x$-axis, the line $y = x$ and the circle $x^2 + y^2 = 32$.
questions.solution:
Finding intersection of $y = x$ and $x^2 + y^2 = 32$:

$$x^2 + x^2 = 32 \;\Rightarrow\; 2x^2 = 32 \;\Rightarrow\; x = 4$$

$$A = \int_0^4 x\,dx + \int_4^{\sqrt{32}} \sqrt{32-x^2}\,dx$$

$$= \left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^4 + \left[\frac{x}{2}\sqrt{32-x^2} + \frac{32}{2}\sin^{-1}\!\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{32}}\right)\right]_4^{\sqrt{32}}$$

$$= 8 + \left[\left(0 + 16\cdot\frac{\pi}{2}\right) - \left(2\sqrt{16} + 16\sin^{-1}\!\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\right)\right]$$

$$= 8 + \left[8\pi - 8 - 16\cdot\frac{\pi}{4}\right]$$

$$= 8 + 8\pi - 8 - 4\pi = 4\pi \text{ sq. units}$$

questions.question:
Find the distance of the point $(-1, -5, -10)$ from the point of intersection of the line:
$$\vec{r} = 2\hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2\hat{k} + \lambda\left(3\hat{i} + 4\hat{j} + 2\hat{k}\right)$$
and the plane $\vec{r}\cdot\left(\hat{i} - \hat{j} + \hat{k}\right) = 5$.
questions.solution:
**Cartesian form of line:**

$$\frac{x-2}{3} = \frac{y+1}{4} = \frac{z-2}{2} = \lambda$$

So $x = 3\lambda+2$, $y = 4\lambda-1$, $z = 2\lambda+2$.

**Cartesian form of plane:** $x - y + z - 5 = 0$

Substituting the line into the plane:

$$(3\lambda+2) - (4\lambda-1) + (2\lambda+2) = 5$$

$$3\lambda + 2 - 4\lambda + 1 + 2\lambda + 2 = 5$$

$$\lambda + 5 = 5 \;\Rightarrow\; \lambda = 0$$

Point of intersection: $x = 2$, $y = -1$, $z = 2$, i.e., $(2, -1, 2)$.

Distance from $(-1,-5,-10)$ to $(2,-1,2)$:

$$d = \sqrt{(2-(-1))^2 + (-1-(-5))^2 + (2-(-10))^2}$$

$$= \sqrt{9 + 16 + 144} = \sqrt{169} = 13 \text{ units}$$

questions.question:
Determine the product:
$$\begin{bmatrix} -4 & 4 & 4 \\ -7 & 1 & 3 \\ 5 & -3 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$$
and use it to solve the system of equations:
$$x - y + z = 4,\quad x - 2y - 2z = 9,\quad 2x + y + 3z = 1$$
questions.solution:
**Product:**

$$\begin{bmatrix} -4 & 4 & 4 \\ -7 & 1 & 3 \\ 5 & -3 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$= \begin{bmatrix} -4+4+8 & 4-8+4 & -4-8+12 \\ -7+1+6 & 7-2+3 & -7-2+9 \\ 5-3-2 & -5+6-1 & 5+6-3 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$= \begin{bmatrix} 8 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 8 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 8 \end{bmatrix} = 8I_3$$

Hence:
$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}^{-1} = \frac{1}{8}\begin{bmatrix} -4 & 4 & 4 \\ -7 & 1 & 3 \\ 5 & -3 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$

The system in matrix form: $AX = B$, where
$$A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix},\quad X = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix},\quad B = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 9 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$X = A^{-1}B = \frac{1}{8}\begin{bmatrix} -4 & 4 & 4 \\ -7 & 1 & 3 \\ 5 & -3 & -1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 9 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$= \frac{1}{8}\begin{bmatrix} -16+36+4 \\ -28+9+3 \\ 20-27-1 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{8}\begin{bmatrix} 24 \\ -16 \\ -8 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ -2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$\therefore x = 3,\quad y = -2,\quad z = -1$$

questions.question: Consider $f : \mathbb{R} - \left\{-\dfrac{4}{3}\right\} \to \mathbb{R} - \left\{\dfrac{4}{3}\right\}$ given by $f(x) = \dfrac{4x+3}{3x+4}$. Show that $f$ is bijective. Find the inverse of $f$ and hence find $f^{-1}(0)$ and $x$ such that $f^{-1}(x) = 2$.
questions.solution:
$$f(x) = \frac{4x+3}{3x+4},\quad x \in \mathbb{R}-\left\{-\frac{4}{3}\right\}$$

**$f$ is one-one:**

Let $x_1, x_2 \in \mathbb{R} - \left\{-\dfrac{4}{3}\right\}$ and $f(x_1) = f(x_2)$:

$$\frac{4x_1+3}{3x_1+4} = \frac{4x_2+3}{3x_2+4}$$

$$\Rightarrow 12x_1x_2 + 16x_1 + 9x_2 + 12 = 12x_1x_2 + 9x_1 + 16x_2 + 12$$

$$\Rightarrow 7x_1 = 7x_2 \Rightarrow x_1 = x_2$$

$\therefore f$ is one-one.

**$f$ is onto:**

Let $k \in \mathbb{R} - \left\{\dfrac{4}{3}\right\}$ be any number. Set $f(x) = k$:

$$\frac{4x+3}{3x+4} = k \Rightarrow x = \frac{4k-3}{4-3k}$$

One can verify $\dfrac{4k-3}{4-3k} \neq -\dfrac{4}{3}$ (since that leads to a contradiction $-9 = -16$).

So $f\!\left(\dfrac{4k-3}{4-3k}\right) = k$, i.e., $f$ is onto.

$\therefore f$ is bijective, hence invertible.

**Inverse of $f$:**

Let $f^{-1}(x) = k$, so $f(k) = x$:
$$\frac{4k+3}{3k+4} = x \Rightarrow k = \frac{4x-3}{4-3x}$$

$$\therefore f^{-1}(x) = \frac{4x-3}{4-3x},\quad x \in \mathbb{R}-\left\{-\frac{4}{3}\right\}$$

$$f^{-1}(0) = \frac{4(0)-3}{4-3(0)} = -\frac{3}{4}$$

When $f^{-1}(x) = 2$:
$$\frac{4x-3}{4-3x} = 2 \Rightarrow 4x-3 = 8-6x \Rightarrow 10x = 11 \Rightarrow x = \frac{11}{10}$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
Let $A = \mathbb{Q} \times \mathbb{Q}$ and let $*$ be a binary operation on $A$ defined by $(a,b)*(c,d) = (ac,\ b+ad)$ for $(a,b),(c,d) \in A$. Determine whether $*$ is commutative and associative. Then, with respect to $*$ on $A$:
**(i)** Find the identity element in $A$.
**(ii)** Find the invertible elements of $A$.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: $*$ is not commutative but is associative; Identity element is $(1, 0)$; Invertible elements are all $(a,b)$ with $a \neq 0$, having inverse $\left(\frac{1}{a}, -\frac{b}{a}\right)$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
**Commutativity:** $(a,b)*(c,d) = (ac, b+ad)$ but $(c,d)*(a,b) = (ca, d+cb)$.

Since $b+ad \neq d+cb$ in general, $*$ is **not commutative**.

**Associativity:**

$$[(a,b)*(c,d)]*(e,f) = (ac, b+ad)*(e,f) = (ace, b+ad+acf)$$

$$(a,b)*[(c,d)*(e,f)] = (a,b)*(ce, d+cf) = (ace, b+a(d+cf)) = (ace, b+ad+acf)$$

Since both are equal, $*$ is **associative**.

**(i) Identity element:**

Let $(e, f)$ be the identity element. For all $(a,b) \in A$:
$$(a,b)*(e,f) = (a,b) \Rightarrow (ae, b+af) = (a,b)$$

$$\Rightarrow ae = a \Rightarrow e = 1, \quad af = 0 \Rightarrow f = 0$$

$$\therefore \text{Identity element} = (1, 0) \in \mathbb{Q}\times\mathbb{Q}$$

**(ii) Invertible elements:**

Let $(a,b) \in A$ have inverse $(c,d)$ such that:
$$(a,b)*(c,d) = (1,0)$$
$$\Rightarrow (ac, b+ad) = (1,0)$$
$$\Rightarrow ac = 1 \Rightarrow c = \frac{1}{a} \quad (a \neq 0)$$
$$ad + b = 0 \Rightarrow d = -\frac{b}{a}$$

$$\therefore (a,b)^{-1} = \left(\frac{1}{a},\ -\frac{b}{a}\right) \quad (a \neq 0)$$

The invertible elements of $A$ are all $(a,b) \in \mathbb{Q}\times\mathbb{Q}$ with $a \neq 0$.

questions.question: Show that the surface area of a closed cuboid with square base and given volume is minimum, when it is a cube.
questions.correctAnswer: Surface area is minimum when the cuboid is a cube (proved).
questions.solution:
Let each side of the square base be $x$ and height be $h$.

Volume: $V = x^2 h \Rightarrow h = \dfrac{V}{x^2}$

Surface area:
$$S = 4hx + 2x^2 = 4\!\left(\frac{V}{x^2}\right)\!x + 2x^2 = \frac{4V}{x} + 2x^2$$

Differentiating w.r.t. $x$:
$$\frac{dS}{dx} = -\frac{4V}{x^2} + 4x \qquad \text{and} \qquad \frac{d^2S}{dx^2} = \frac{8V}{x^3} + 4$$

Setting $\dfrac{dS}{dx} = 0$:

$$4x = \frac{4V}{x^2} \Rightarrow x^3 = V \Rightarrow x = V^{1/3}$$

At $x = V^{1/3}$: $\dfrac{d^2S}{dx^2} = \dfrac{8V}{V} + 4 = 12 > 0$.

$\therefore S$ is minimum when $x = V^{1/3}$.

And the corresponding height:
$$h = \frac{V}{x^2} = \frac{V}{V^{2/3}} = V^{1/3} = x$$

Since $h = x$, all sides are equal $\Rightarrow$ it is a **cube**.

questions.question: Using the method of integration, find the area of the triangle $ABC$, coordinates of whose vertices are $A(4,1)$, $B(6,6)$ and $C(8,4)$.
questions.solution:
**Equation of $AB$:**
$$y - 1 = \frac{6-1}{6-4}(x-4) \Rightarrow y = \frac{5x}{2} - 9$$

**Equation of $BC$:**
$$y - 6 = \frac{4-6}{8-6}(x-6) \Rightarrow y = -x + 12$$

**Equation of $AC$:**
$$y - 1 = \frac{4-1}{8-4}(x-4) \Rightarrow y = \frac{3x}{4} - 2$$

$$\text{Area of }\triangle ABC = \int_4^6\!\left(\frac{5x}{2}-9\right)dx + \int_6^8\!(-x+12)\,dx - \int_4^8\!\left(\frac{3x}{4}-2\right)dx$$

$$= \left[\frac{5x^2}{4}-9x\right]_4^6 + \left[\frac{-x^2}{2}+12x\right]_6^8 - \left[\frac{3x^2}{8}-2x\right]_4^8$$

$$= \left[(45-54)-(20-36)\right] + \left[(-32+96)-(-18+72)\right] - \left[(24-16)-(6-8)\right]$$

$$= \left[-9+16\right] + \left[64-54\right] - \left[8+2\right]$$

$$= 7 + 10 - 10 = 7 \text{ sq. units}$$

alternativeQuestion.question: Find the area enclosed between the parabola $4y = 3x^2$ and the straight line $3x - 2y + 12 = 0$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
Parabola: $4y = 3x^2 \quad \cdots(1)$

Line: $3x - 2y + 12 = 0 \Rightarrow y = \dfrac{3x+12}{2} \quad \cdots(2)$

Substituting (2) into (1):
$$4 \cdot \frac{3x+12}{2} = 3x^2 \Rightarrow 6x + 24 = 3x^2 \Rightarrow x^2 - 2x - 8 = 0$$
$$\Rightarrow (x-4)(x+2) = 0 \Rightarrow x = 4,\ x = -2$$

When $x=4$: $y=12$; when $x=-2$: $y=3$.

$$\text{Required Area} = \int_{-2}^{4}\!\left(\frac{3x+12}{2} - \frac{3x^2}{4}\right)dx$$

$$= \frac{3}{4}\int_{-2}^{4}(8 + 2x - x^2)\,dx$$

$$= \frac{3}{4}\left[8x + x^2 - \frac{x^3}{3}\right]_{-2}^{4}$$

$$= \frac{3}{4}\left[\left(32 + 16 - \frac{64}{3}\right) - \left(-16 + 4 + \frac{8}{3}\right)\right]$$

$$= \frac{3}{4}\left[48 - \frac{64}{3} + 12 - \frac{8}{3}\right]$$

$$= \frac{3}{4}\left[36 - 24\right] = \frac{3}{4} \times 36 = 27 \text{ sq. units}$$

questions.question: Find the particular solution of the differential equation $(x - y)\dfrac{dy}{dx} = (x + 2y)$, given that $y = 0$ when $x = 1$.
questions.solution:
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{x+2y}{x-y}$$

Let $y = Vx$, so $\dfrac{dy}{dx} = V + x\dfrac{dV}{dx}$:

$$V + x\frac{dV}{dx} = \frac{x + 2Vx}{x - Vx} = \frac{1+2V}{1-V}$$

$$x\frac{dV}{dx} = \frac{1+2V}{1-V} - V = \frac{1+2V - V + V^2}{1-V} = \frac{1+V+V^2}{1-V}$$

Separating variables:
$$\int\frac{1-V}{1+V+V^2}\,dV = \int\frac{dx}{x}$$

$$-\frac{1}{2}\int\frac{2V+1}{1+V+V^2}\,dV + \frac{3}{2}\int\frac{dV}{1+V+V^2} = \int\frac{dx}{x}$$

For the second integral, complete the square: $1 + V + V^2 = \left(V + \dfrac{1}{2}\right)^2 + \dfrac{3}{4}$:

$$-\frac{1}{2}\log|1+V+V^2| + \sqrt{3}\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{V+\frac{1}{2}}{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}}\right) = \log|x| + C$$

Substituting back $V = y/x$:

$$-\frac{1}{2}\log\left|1+\frac{y}{x}+\frac{y^2}{x^2}\right| + \sqrt{3}\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{\dfrac{2y}{x}+1}{\sqrt{3}}\right) = \log|x| + C$$

**Applying initial condition** $y = 0$, $x = 1$:

$$0 + \sqrt{3}\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right) = 0 + C$$

$$C = \sqrt{3}\cdot\frac{\pi}{6} = \frac{\pi\sqrt{3}}{6}$$

**Particular solution:**

$$-\frac{1}{2}\log\left|1+\frac{y}{x}+\frac{y^2}{x^2}\right| + \sqrt{3}\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{2y/x+1}{\sqrt{3}}\right) = \log|x| + \sqrt{3}\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)$$

questions.question: Find the coordinates of the point where the line through the points $(3, -4, -5)$ and $(2, -3, 1)$ crosses the plane determined by the points $(1, 2, 3)$, $(4, 2, -3)$ and $(0, 4, 3)$.
questions.solution:
**Equation of line** through $(3,-4,-5)$ and $(2,-3,1)$:

Direction ratios: $(2-3, -3-(-4), 1-(-5)) = (-1, 1, 6)$

$$\frac{x-3}{-1} = \frac{y+4}{1} = \frac{z+5}{6} = k \quad \cdots(1)$$

General point on line: $P(-k+3, k-4, 6k-5)$

**Equation of plane** through $(1,2,3)$, $(4,2,-3)$ and $(0,4,3)$:

$$\begin{vmatrix} x-1 & y-2 & z-3 \\ 3 & 0 & -6 \\ -1 & 2 & 0 \end{vmatrix} = 0$$

$$(x-1)(0+12) - (y-2)(0-6) + (z-3)(6-0) = 0$$

$$12(x-1) + 6(y-2) + 6(z-3) = 0$$

$$2x + y + z - 7 = 0 \quad \cdots(2)$$

Substituting the general point into plane equation (2):
$$2(-k+3) + (k-4) + (6k-5) - 7 = 0$$

$$-2k + 6 + k - 4 + 6k - 5 - 7 = 0$$

$$5k - 10 = 0 \Rightarrow k = 2$$

Coordinates of $P$:
$$x = -2+3 = 1, \quad y = 2-4 = -2, \quad z = 12-5 = 7$$

$$\therefore P = (1, -2, 7)$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
A variable plane which remains at a constant distance $3p$ from the origin cuts the coordinate axes at $A$, $B$, $C$. Show that the locus of the centroid of triangle $ABC$ is:
$$\frac{1}{x^2}+\frac{1}{y^2}+\frac{1}{z^2} = \frac{1}{p^2}$$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
Let the variable plane cut the coordinate axes at $A(a, 0, 0)$, $B(0, b, 0)$, $C(0, 0, c)$.

Equation of the plane: $\dfrac{x}{a} + \dfrac{y}{b} + \dfrac{z}{c} = 1$

Distance from origin to the plane:
$$d = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{a^2}+\frac{1}{b^2}+\frac{1}{c^2}}} = 3p$$

$$\Rightarrow \frac{1}{a^2}+\frac{1}{b^2}+\frac{1}{c^2} = \frac{1}{9p^2} \quad \cdots(1)$$

Let the centroid of $\triangle ABC$ be $(x, y, z)$:
$$x = \frac{a}{3},\quad y = \frac{b}{3},\quad z = \frac{c}{3}$$
$$\Rightarrow a = 3x,\quad b = 3y,\quad c = 3z$$

Substituting into (1):
$$\frac{1}{9x^2}+\frac{1}{9y^2}+\frac{1}{9z^2} = \frac{1}{9p^2}$$

$$\Rightarrow \frac{1}{x^2}+\frac{1}{y^2}+\frac{1}{z^2} = \frac{1}{p^2}$$

questions.question: Let N denote the set of all natural numbers and R be the relation on $N \times N$ defined by $(a, b)\,R\,(c, d)$ if $ad(b+c) = bc(a+d)$. Show that R is an equivalence relation.
questions.correctAnswer: R is an equivalence relation (proved by showing reflexivity, symmetry, and transitivity).
questions.solution:
**Reflexivity:** For all $(a,b) \in N\times N$:
$$ab(b+a) = ba(a+b) \implies (a,b)\,R\,(a,b)$$
∴ R is reflexive.

**Symmetry:** Let $(a,b)\,R\,(c,d)$, so $ad(b+c) = bc(a+d)$.
Then $cb(d+a) = da(c+b)$, which means $(c,d)\,R\,(a,b)$.
∴ R is symmetric.

**Transitivity:** Let $(a,b)\,R\,(c,d)$ and $(c,d)\,R\,(e,f)$ for $a,b,c,d,e,f \in N$.
$$ad(b+c)=bc(a+d) \implies \frac{1}{c}+\frac{1}{b} = \frac{1}{d}+\frac{1}{a} \quad \cdots(A)$$
$$cf(d+e)=de(c+f) \implies \frac{1}{e}+\frac{1}{d} = \frac{1}{f}+\frac{1}{c} \quad \cdots(B)$$
Adding $(A)$ and $(B)$:
$$\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{e} = \frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{f} \implies af(b+e) = be(a+f)$$
Hence $(a,b)\,R\,(e,f)$, so R is transitive.

From reflexivity, symmetry, and transitivity, R is an equivalence relation. $\blacksquare$

questions.question: Using integration, find the area of the triangle formed by the positive x-axis and the tangent and normal to the circle $x^2 + y^2 = 4$ at $(1, \sqrt{3})$.
questions.solution:
Equation of normal (OP): $y = \sqrt{3}x$
Equation of tangent (PQ): The tangent to $x^2+y^2=4$ at $(1,\sqrt{3})$ is:
$$x + \sqrt{3}y = 4 \implies y = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}(4-x)$$
Coordinates of Q: $(4, 0)$
Required area:
$$= \int_0^1 \sqrt{3}x\,dx + \int_1^4 \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}(4-x)\,dx$$
$$= \sqrt{3}\left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^1 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[4x - \frac{x^2}{2}\right]_1^4$$
$$= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[\left(16-8\right)-\left(4-\frac{1}{2}\right)\right]$$
$$= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\cdot\frac{9}{2} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + \frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2} = 2\sqrt{3} \text{ sq. units}$$

alternativeQuestion.question: Evaluate $\displaystyle\int_1^3 (e^{2-3x} + x^2 + 1)\,dx$ as a limit of a sum.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
Here $a=1$, $b=3$, $h = \dfrac{2}{n}$.
$$\int_1^3(e^{2-3x}+x^2+1)\,dx = \lim_{h\to 0} h\bigl[f(1)+f(1+h)+\cdots+f(1+(n-1)h)\bigr]$$
$$= \lim_{h\to 0} h\left[e^{-1}\left(1+e^{-3h}+e^{-6h}+\cdots+e^{-3(n-1)h}\right) + 2n + 2h\left(1+2+\cdots+(n-1)^2\right)\right]$$
Taking the limit as $h\to 0$ (with $nh = 2$):
$$= e^{-1}\cdot\frac{e^{-6}-1}{-3} + 4 + 4 + \frac{8}{3} = -e^{-1}\cdot\frac{e^{-6}-1}{3} + \frac{32}{3}$$

questions.question: Solve the differential equation: $(\tan^{-1}y - x)\,dy = (1+y^2)\,dx$.
questions.solution:
Rewriting as a linear ODE in $x$:
$$\frac{dx}{dy} + \frac{1}{1+y^2}\cdot x = \frac{\tan^{-1}y}{1+y^2}$$
Integrating factor: $e^{\tan^{-1}y}$
Solution:
$$x\cdot e^{\tan^{-1}y} = \int \frac{\tan^{-1}y \cdot e^{\tan^{-1}y}}{1+y^2}\,dy$$
Let $t = \tan^{-1}y$:
$$= \int t\,e^t\,dt = te^t - e^t + c = e^{\tan^{-1}y}(\tan^{-1}y - 1) + c$$
Therefore:
$$x = \tan^{-1}y - 1 + c\,e^{-\tan^{-1}y}$$

alternativeQuestion.question: Find the particular solution of the differential equation $\dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{xy}{x^2+y^2}$ given that $y = 1$ when $x = 0$.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
$$\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{y/x}{1+(y/x)^2}$$
Put $y = vx$, so $\dfrac{dy}{dx} = v + x\dfrac{dv}{dx}$:
$$v + x\frac{dv}{dx} = \frac{v}{1+v^2}$$
$$x\frac{dv}{dx} = \frac{v}{1+v^2} - v = \frac{-v^3}{1+v^2}$$
$$\int\frac{v^2+1}{v^3}\,dv = -\int\frac{dx}{x}$$
$$\log|v| - \frac{1}{2v^2} = -\log|x| + c$$
$$\log\frac{y}{x} - \frac{x^2}{2y^2} = -\log x + c \implies \log y - \frac{x^2}{2y^2} = c$$
Applying $x = 0$, $y = 1$: $\log 1 - 0 = c \implies c = 0$.
$$\therefore \log y - \frac{x^2}{2y^2} = 0$$

questions.question: If lines $\dfrac{x-1}{2} = \dfrac{y+1}{3} = \dfrac{z-1}{4}$ and $\dfrac{x-3}{1} = \dfrac{y+k}{2} = \dfrac{z}{1}$ intersect, then find the value of $k$ and hence find the equation of the plane containing these lines.
questions.solution:
Any point on the first line: $(2\lambda+1,\; 3\lambda-1,\; 4\lambda+1)$.
Any point on the second line: $(\mu+3,\; 2\mu-k,\; \mu)$.
For intersection, equating:
$$\frac{2\lambda+1-3}{1} = \frac{3\lambda-1+k}{2} = \frac{4\lambda+1}{1}$$
From the equations: $\lambda = -\dfrac{3}{2}$, hence $k = \dfrac{9}{2}$.
Equation of the plane containing both lines:
$$\begin{vmatrix} x-1 & y+1 & z-1 \\ 2 & 3 & 4 \\ 1 & 2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 0$$
$$\implies -5(x-1) + 2(y+1) + 1(z-1) = 0$$
$$\implies 5x - 2y - z - 6 = 0$$

questions.question: If A and B are two independent events such that $P(\bar{A}\cap B) = \dfrac{2}{15}$ and $P(A\cap\bar{B}) = \dfrac{1}{6}$, then find $P(A)$ and $P(B)$.

$$P(\bar{A}\cap B) = P(\bar{A})\cdot P(B) = (1-P(A))\cdot P(B) = \frac{2}{15} \quad \cdots(i)$$

questions.question: Find the local maxima and local minima of the function $f(x) = \sin x - \cos x$, $0 < x < 2\pi$. Also find the local maximum and local minimum values.
questions.correctAnswer: Local maximum at $x = \dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ with value $\sqrt{2}$; Local minimum at $x = \dfrac{7\pi}{4}$ with value $-\sqrt{2}$
questions.solution:
$$f'(x) = \cos x + \sin x$$
Setting $f'(x) = 0$: $\tan x = -1 \implies x = \dfrac{3\pi}{4},\; \dfrac{7\pi}{4}$
$$f''(x) = -\sin x + \cos x$$
At $x = \dfrac{3\pi}{4}$:
$$f''\!\left(\frac{3\pi}{4}\right) = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} - \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = -\sqrt{2} < 0 \implies \text{Local Maxima}$$
$$f\!\left(\frac{3\pi}{4}\right) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = \sqrt{2}$$
At $x = \dfrac{7\pi}{4}$:
$$f''\!\left(\frac{7\pi}{4}\right) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = \sqrt{2} > 0 \implies \text{Local Minima}$$
$$f\!\left(\frac{7\pi}{4}\right) = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = -\sqrt{2}$$

questions.question: Two schools A and B want to award their selected students on the values of sincerity, truthfulness and helpfulness. School A wants to award ₹$x$ each, ₹$y$ each and ₹$z$ each for the three respective values to 3, 2 and 1 students respectively with a total award money of ₹1,600. School B wants to spend ₹2,300 to award its 4, 1 and 3 students on the respective values (by giving the same award money to the three values as before). If the total amount of award for one prize on each value is ₹900, using matrices, find the award money for each value. Apart from these three values, suggest one more value which should be considered for award.
questions.solution:
Setting up the matrix equation $DX = E$:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 & 1 \\ 4 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1600 \\ 2300 \\ 900 \end{bmatrix}$$

**Computing $|D|$:**

$$|D| = \begin{vmatrix} 3 & 2 & 1 \\ 4 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 3(1-3) - 2(4-3) + 1(4-1) = -6 - 2 + 3 = -5 \neq 0$$

**Cofactor Matrix of D:**

$$C = \begin{bmatrix} -2 & -1 & 3 \\ -1 & 2 & -1 \\ 5 & -5 & -5 \end{bmatrix}$$

**Adjoint of D** (transpose of cofactor matrix):

$$\text{adj}(D) = \begin{bmatrix} -2 & -1 & 5 \\ -1 & 2 & -5 \\ 3 & -1 & -5 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$D^{-1} = \frac{1}{|D|}\text{adj}(D) = \frac{1}{-5}\begin{bmatrix} -2 & -1 & 5 \\ -1 & 2 & -5 \\ 3 & -1 & -5 \end{bmatrix}$$

**Solution $X = D^{-1}E$:**

$$\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{-5}\begin{bmatrix} -2 & -1 & 5 \\ -1 & 2 & -5 \\ 3 & -1 & -5 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1600 \\ 2300 \\ 900 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 200 \\ 300 \\ 400 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$\therefore x = ₹200,\quad y = ₹300,\quad z = ₹400$$

**One more value** that could be considered for award: **Punctuality**.

questions.question: Show that the altitude of the right circular cone of maximum volume that can be inscribed in a sphere of radius $r$ is $\dfrac{4r}{3}$. Also show that the maximum volume of the cone is $\dfrac{8}{27}$ of the volume of the sphere.
questions.solution:
In the cone inscribed in a sphere of radius $r$, let the cone have height $h$ and base radius $R$. By the Pythagorean theorem:

$$(h - r)^2 + R^2 = r^2 \implies R^2 = r^2 - (h-r)^2$$

**Volume of cone:**

$$V = \frac{1}{3}\pi R^2 h = \frac{1}{3}\pi\left[r^2 - (h-r)^2\right]h$$

$$= \frac{\pi}{3}\left[r^2 h - h^3 + 2h^2 r - r^2 h\right] = \frac{\pi}{3}\left[2h^2 r - h^3\right]$$

**For maximum volume**, $\dfrac{dV}{dh} = 0$:

$$\frac{dV}{dh} = \frac{\pi}{3}[4hr - 3h^2] = 0$$

$$\implies 4hr = 3h^2 \implies h = \frac{4r}{3}$$

**Verifying maximum** ($d^2V/dh^2 < 0$):

$$\frac{d^2V}{dh^2} = \frac{\pi}{3}[4r - 6h]$$

At $h = \dfrac{4r}{3}$:
$$\frac{d^2V}{dh^2} = \frac{\pi}{3}\left[4r - 8r\right] = -\frac{4\pi r}{3} < 0 \quad \checkmark$$

So $h = \dfrac{4r}{3}$ gives **maximum volume**.

**Maximum Volume of cone** at $h = \dfrac{4r}{3}$:

$$R^2 = r^2 - \left(\frac{4r}{3} - r\right)^2 = r^2 - \frac{r^2}{9} = \frac{8r^2}{9}$$

$$V_{\max} = \frac{1}{3}\pi \cdot \frac{8r^2}{9} \cdot \frac{4r}{3} = \frac{32\pi r^3}{81} = \frac{8}{27} \cdot \frac{4\pi r^3}{3}$$

$$V_{\max} = \frac{8}{27} \times \text{Volume of sphere} \qquad \textbf{Proved}$$

questions.question:
Evaluate:
$$\int \frac{1}{\cos^4 x + \sin^4 x}\, dx$$
questions.solution:
$$I = \int \frac{1}{\cos^4 x + \sin^4 x}\, dx$$

Dividing numerator and denominator by $\cos^4 x$:

$$= \int \frac{\sec^4 x}{1 + \tan^4 x}\, dx = \int \frac{(1 + \tan^2 x)\sec^2 x}{1 + \tan^4 x}\, dx$$

Put $\tan x = t \implies \sec^2 x\, dx = dt$:

$$= \int \frac{1 + t^2}{1 + t^4}\, dt$$

Dividing numerator and denominator by $t^2$:

$$= \int \frac{\frac{1}{t^2} + 1}{\frac{1}{t^2} + t^2}\, dt = \int \frac{1 + \frac{1}{t^2}}{\left(t - \frac{1}{t}\right)^2 + 2}\, dt$$

Put $t - \dfrac{1}{t} = z \implies \left(1 + \dfrac{1}{t^2}\right)dt = dz$:

$$= \int \frac{dz}{z^2 + 2} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{z}{\sqrt{2}}\right) + C$$

$$= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{t - \frac{1}{t}}{\sqrt{2}}\right) + C$$

$$= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{\tan x - \cot x}{\sqrt{2}}\right) + C$$

questions.question: Using integration, find the area of the region bounded by the triangle whose vertices are $(-1, 2)$, $(1, 5)$ and $(3, 4)$.
questions.solution:
Let $A = (-1, 2)$, $B = (1, 5)$, $C = (3, 4)$.

**Equation of line AB:**
$$y - 5 = \frac{2-5}{-1-1}(x-1) = \frac{3}{2}(x-1) \implies y = \frac{3x+7}{2}$$

**Equation of line BC:**
$$y - 5 = \frac{4-5}{3-1}(x-1) = -\frac{1}{2}(x-1) \implies y = \frac{11-x}{2}$$

**Equation of line AC:**
$$y - 4 = \frac{2-4}{-1-3}(x-3) = \frac{1}{2}(x-3) \implies y = \frac{x+5}{2}$$

**Area of triangle** = Area under AB + Area under BC $-$ Area under AC:

$$\text{Area} = \int_{-1}^{1} \frac{3x+7}{2}\,dx + \int_{1}^{3} \frac{11-x}{2}\,dx - \int_{-1}^{3} \frac{x+5}{2}\,dx$$

**Evaluating each integral:**

$$\int_{-1}^{1} \frac{3x+7}{2}\,dx = \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{3x^2}{2} + 7x\right]_{-1}^{1} = \frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\frac{3}{2}+7\right) - \left(\frac{3}{2}-7\right)\right] = \frac{1}{2}[14] = 7$$

$$\int_{1}^{3} \frac{11-x}{2}\,dx = \frac{1}{2}\left[11x - \frac{x^2}{2}\right]_{1}^{3} = \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{57}{2} - \frac{21}{2}\right] = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 18 = 9$$

$$\int_{-1}^{3} \frac{x+5}{2}\,dx = \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{x^2}{2} + 5x\right]_{-1}^{3} = \frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\frac{9}{2}+15\right) - \left(\frac{1}{2}-5\right)\right] = \frac{1}{2}[24] = 12$$

$$\text{Area} = 7 + 9 - 12 = 4 \text{ square units}$$

questions.question: Find the equation of the plane through the line of intersection of the planes $x + y + z = 1$ and $2x + 3y + 4z = 5$ which is perpendicular to the plane $x - y + z = 0$. Also find the distance of the plane obtained above from the origin.
questions.solution:
The equation of any plane through the line of intersection of $P_1$ and $P_2$ is:

$$P_1 + \lambda P_2 = 0$$

$$(x + y + z - 1) + \lambda(2x + 3y + 4z - 5) = 0$$

$$(1 + 2\lambda)x + (1 + 3\lambda)y + (1 + 4\lambda)z + (-1 - 5\lambda) = 0 \quad \cdots (1)$$

Since this plane is **perpendicular** to $x - y + z = 0$, using $a_1a_2 + b_1b_2 + c_1c_2 = 0$:

$$(1 + 2\lambda)(1) + (1 + 3\lambda)(-1) + (1 + 4\lambda)(1) = 0$$
$$1 + 2\lambda - 1 - 3\lambda + 1 + 4\lambda = 0$$
$$3\lambda + 1 = 0 \implies \lambda = -\frac{1}{3}$$

Substituting $\lambda = -\dfrac{1}{3}$ in $(1)$:

$$\left(1 - \frac{2}{3}\right)x + (1-1)y + \left(1 - \frac{4}{3}\right)z + \left(-1 + \frac{5}{3}\right) = 0$$

$$\frac{x}{3} - \frac{z}{3} + \frac{2}{3} = 0 \implies x - z + 2 = 0$$

**Distance from origin:**
$$d = \frac{|0 - 0 + 2|}{\sqrt{1^2 + 0^2 + (-1)^2}} = \frac{2}{\sqrt{2}} = \sqrt{2}$$

alternativeQuestion.solution:
General point on the line: $(2 + 3\lambda,\ -4 + 4\lambda,\ 2 + 2\lambda)$

Substituting into the plane $\vec{r}\cdot(\hat{i} - 2\hat{j} + \hat{k}) = 0$:

$$(2 + 3\lambda)(1) + (-4 + 4\lambda)(-2) + (2 + 2\lambda)(1) = 0$$

$$2 + 3\lambda + 8 - 8\lambda + 2 + 2\lambda = 0$$

$$12 - 3\lambda = 0 \implies \lambda = 4$$

$$(2 + 12,\ -4 + 16,\ 2 + 8) = (14,\ 12,\ 10)$$

**Distance from $(2, 12, 5)$:**
$$d = \sqrt{(14-2)^2 + (12-12)^2 + (10-5)^2} = \sqrt{144 + 0 + 25} = \sqrt{169} = 13$$

questions.question: A manufacturing company makes two types of teaching aids A and B of Mathematics for class XII. Each type of A requires 9 labour hours of fabricating and 1 labour hour for finishing. Each type of B requires 12 labour hours for fabricating and 3 labour hours for finishing. For fabricating and finishing, the maximum labour hours available per week are 180 and 30 respectively. The company makes a profit of ₹80 on each piece of type A and ₹120 on each piece of type B. How many pieces of type A and type B should be manufactured per week to get a maximum profit? Make it as an LPP and solve graphically. What is the maximum profit per week?
questions.correctAnswer: 12 pieces of type A and 6 pieces of type B; Maximum profit = ₹1,680
questions.solution:
Let $x$ = pieces of type A and $y$ = pieces of type B manufactured per week.

**Objective Function:** Maximize $Z = 80x + 120y$

**Subject to constraints:**
$$9x + 12y \leq 180 \implies 3x + 4y \leq 60$$
$$x + 3y \leq 30$$
$$x \geq 0,\quad y \geq 0$$

**Corner Points and their objective values:**

| Corner Point | $Z = 80x + 120y$ |
|---|---|
| $(0, 0)$ | $0$ |
| $(20, 0)$ | $1600$ |
| $(12, 6)$ | $960 + 720 = 1680$ |
| $(0, 10)$ | $1200$ |

The feasible corner points are $(0,0)$, $(20,0)$, $(12,6)$, $(0,10)$.

The **maximum profit** is at $(12, 6)$:

$$Z_{\max} = 80(12) + 120(6) = 960 + 720 = ₹1680$$

**∴ 12 pieces of type A and 6 pieces of type B** should be manufactured per week for a maximum profit of **₹1,680**.

questions.question: There are three coins. One is a two-headed coin (having head on both faces), another is a biased coin that comes up heads 75% of the times and the third is also a biased coin that comes up tails 40% of the times. One of the three coins is chosen at random and tossed, and it shows heads. What is the probability that it was the two-headed coin?
questions.solution:
Let:
- $A$ = event that two-headed coin is chosen
- $B$ = event that biased coin (heads 75%) is chosen
- $C$ = event that biased coin (tails 40%) is chosen
- $H$ = event that head is obtained

$$P(A) = P(B) = P(C) = \frac{1}{3}$$

$$P(H|A) = 1, \quad P(H|B) = \frac{3}{4}, \quad P(H|C) = 0.6$$

Using **Bayes' Theorem**:

$$P\!\left(\frac{A}{H}\right) = \frac{P(H|A) \cdot P(A)}{P(H|A) \cdot P(A) + P(H|B) \cdot P(B) + P(H|C) \cdot P(C)}$$

$$= \frac{1 \cdot \dfrac{1}{3}}{1 \cdot \dfrac{1}{3} + \dfrac{3}{4} \cdot \dfrac{1}{3} + 0.6 \cdot \dfrac{1}{3}}$$

$$= \frac{1}{1 + 0.75 + 0.6} = \frac{1}{2.35} = \frac{100}{235} = \frac{20}{47}$$
